head.title: POSTINGS: $4,800 to $18,000 a Month; In Village, Living Above The Store

hedline.hl1: POSTINGS: $4,800 to $18,000 a Month; In Village, Living Above The Store

abstract.p: Six loft-style luxury apartments are being constructed in two nondescript low-rise buildings atop D'Agostino supermarket in heart of Manhattan's Greenwich Village that are expected to fetch monthly rents of $4,800 to $18,000; photo (M)

block.p: A walkup over a grocery for $216,000 a year?

From the outside, there is no hint that the two nondescript low-rise buildings that sit atop portions of a D'Agostino supermarket in the heart of Greenwich Village contain luxury apartments being offered for rent for as much as $18,000 a month.
A walkup over a grocery for $216,000 a year?

From the outside, there is no hint that the two nondescript low-rise buildings that sit atop portions of a D'Agostino supermarket in the heart of Greenwich Village contain luxury apartments being offered for rent for as much as $18,000 a month.

Indeed even the interior entrances of the two connected buildings that sit next to each other in an L-shaped configuration at Greenwich and Bethune Streets represent understatement carried to great lengths. There are no lobbies, no doormen, not even elevators.
But inside, there is little stinting on luxury in the six loft-style apartments being carved out of what was once a steel fabricating plant (Greenwich Street) and a coal yard (Bethune).

Among the amenities in the units, which range from a studio to a four-bedroom, 2,300-square-foot penthouse, are outdoor decks that run as much as 2,500 square feet, 10-foot ceilings, in one case a 65-foot living room, and double-sided fireplaces.
Even the one studio in the project has a large kitchen and balcony and, with 1,000 square feet, has sufficient space to create a separate bedroom. It will rent for $4,800 a month.
To conform with requirements of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, the windows are modern interpretations of the old industrial sash style.

''Because the buildings are in the Greenwich Village Historic District, it took quite a bit to design and get it accepted by the landmarks commission,'' said Mark Scott, the architect on the project. ''It had to be in context of the existing fabric.''

The developer is Greenwich Associates, a partnership of members of the D'Agostino family that also operates the ground-floor supermarket. ''We had owned the building for a number of years and realized we had the opportunity to do something better there,'' said Nicholas D'Agostino 3rd, vice president for corporate administration of the supermarket chain.
It is the family's first foray into residential real estate, but probably not its last.
''It depends on what opportunities come around,'' Mr. D'Agostino said. ''It is important to have commercial property downstairs because that is our market.''
Is he considering living above the store himself? ''It might be nice to retire there,'' Mr. D'Agostino said, ''but I can't consider it seriously now. I have four young children.''
